item.title: The CJEU enhances public availability of legal counsel on international agreements.
item.description:
A Taste of Transparency: The CJEU Rules on Access to Legal Advice in Treaty Negotiations Introduction Data protection remains a point of contention between the EU and the USA. Disagreements existed even before Edward Snowden’s revelations about US surveillance practices, particularly regarding access to passenger data and financial transactions. These disputes were ultimately settled through treaties regulating US access for programs like the Terrorist Finance Tracking Program (TFTP). Notably, the European Parliament initially rejected the first TFTP agreement, only approving a revised version after amendments...

item.title: Access to documents: The Council may choose not to enforce a significant CJEU ruling.
item.description:
Steve Peers The EU is frequently criticized for its lack of transparency, particularly concerning its legislative processes. Ideally, these processes should be as open as those in national legislatures, allowing public access to draft legislation. However, despite a 2001 regulation on public access to documents, EU transparency in this area remains an issue. Within the Council, some Member States prefer to keep their positions confidential during negotiations. This secrecy undermines the idea that citizens, through their national parliaments, can hold their governments accountable for actions taken within the Council...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/access-to-documents-the-council-may-choose-not-to-enforce-a-significant-cjeu-ruling/

item.title: Exploring the European Parliament's Closed Reading Rooms: Shedding Light on Transparency in the EU
item.description:
Dr Vigjilenca Abazi Assistant Professor of European Law Maastricht University Documents related to various topics, such as Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) negotiations, EU Food Safety Authority oversight, and tax justice, share a common factor: accessing them requires select Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) to participate in closed reading rooms. This blog post will examine how this departure from transparent parliamentary oversight is becoming increasingly common and question its potential impact on public access to documents requests...

item.title: Regarding knowledge as power: the transparency of procedures for making EU laws
item.description:
Päivi Leino (University of Helsinki) A key promise made during the adoption of the Lisbon Treaty was increased transparency in EU law-making. However, this has not yet been realized. Access to documents related to EU legislative processes, especially “trilogues” (informal meetings between the European Parliament, the Council, and the Commission), has become a significant concern. This issue is highlighted in the new Interinstitutional Agreement (IIA) on Better Regulation, the European Ombudsman’s public consultation on trilogue transparency, and a legal appeal by a former LIBE Committee Secretariat head against the European Parliament’s refusal to grant full access to legislative documents...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/regarding-knowledge-as-power-the-transparency-of-procedures-for-making-eu-laws/
